summary: the introduction of molecular diagnostic methods has significantly improved the epidemiological investigation of viral pneumonia in the ICU in recent years with increased potential for detection of a wide array of viruses. viruses accounted for 20–50% of total infections in patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with severe respiratory distress [1–4]. the aims of this retrospective study were: i) to describe the frequency of respiratory viruses in patients admitted to the ICU during a winter-spring season. ii) to monitor the presence of polymorphisms at position 222 in the HA gene of influenza A/H1N1pdm09 strains. diagnostic and clinical management of patients admitted to hospitals in the Lombardy Region with severe and moderate influenza like illness (ILI) included prospective influenza A detection, subtyping and sequencing. the latter two were centralized at two Regional Reference Laboratories. HA Sanger sequencing and phylogenetic analysis were performed on quantified BAL and Brasp specimens. the complete influenza A/H1N1pdm09 HA gene was amplified directly from clinical specimens using the SuperScriptIII One-Step RT-PCR amplification kit. a bootstrap analysis with 1,000 replicates was performed. presence of polymorphisms. a panel of laboratory-developed real-time RT-PCR or real-time PCR [14,15] were used. purified PCR products were sequenced using the BigDye Terminator Cycle-Sequencing kit. sequences were assembled using the Sequencher software, version 4.6. amplicon Primers targeting the influenza A HA gene spanning codons 180–286 were used to amplify the region containing codon 222. the reaction was carried out using the FastStart High-Fidelity PCR kit (Roche Applied Science) dilution of 1109 molecules/l was performed for each amplicon. mixture was then pooled in an equimolar concentration. purified pool was clonally amplified by emulsion PCR. p-values of 0.05 were considered statistically significant. patients and samples A total of 150 respiratory samples from 88 patients admitted to ICUs with severe respiratory syndrome were analyzed. 2/23 (8.7%) had coinfections with influenza A/H1N1pdm09 and Candida spp, 1/23 (4.3%) with A/H1N1pdm09 and Aspergillus spp, 1/23 (4.3%) with influenza A and K. pneumoniae. 19/23 (82.7%) were negative (data not shown). total of 51 (36 NS and 13 BAL or Brasp) respiratory samples from 41 H1N1pdm09-positive ICU patients were analyzed by both Sanger and NGS sequencing. no sequencing data were obtained in respiratory samples of 15/41 (31.7%) ICU patients due to low viral load. 22/26 strains carried the wild-type 222D codon.
